author: @user-vr8hg1eo4d
text: 13:31 / 15:28  This code will help things make sense and remember, everything in Python in an object, including functions, right? anyway, : def get_math_op(symbol):     def mul(num1, num2):         return num1 * num2      def add(num1, num2):         return num1 + num2      def sub(num1, num2):         return num1 - num2      def div(num1, num2):         return num1 / num2      def mod(num1, num2):         return num1 % num2     """     of course there are missing edge cases such as when operation     mentioned is not one of the functions we have     """      funcs  = {"*": mul, "+": add, "-": sub, "/": div, "%": mod}          return funcs[symbol]        operand1, symbol, operand2 = input("enter your simple equation. example: 1 + 2\n-> ").split()  func = get_math_op(symbol)  operand1, operand2 = int(operand1), int(operand2) print(func(operand1, operand2))    Copy and paste it and play around with it it will make things betterfor you and remember,  you need to learn how to learn in order to learn anything check learning how to learn course, book and website prof barbra okley and check in 2 hours Learn like a pro from edx

author: @FaridTaba
text: "Uncomment out" is grammatically incorrect, confusing and clunky. You comment" things "out" (as in "out of the execution flow"). With "uncomment", a preposition is unnecessary. You may "uncomment [things] [back] *in*", although that sounds quite cumbersome too.

author: @john_hind
text: Having recently come to Python from Lua, your videos have been very useful. However I do not agree that Python functions can be described as 'first class'. If they were, the hobbled 'lambda' version would be redundant and you would be able to write a full function definition anywhere a function reference is legal. For example, you should be able to make a list of functions by nesting function definitions within a list constructor. When a language has truly first class functions (like Lua does) a function definition is syntactically a constructor for anonymous function objects in exactly the same way a string or number literal, or a tuple constructor is for those object types.

author: @dwivedys
text: Changed mem_profile since it does not work in python 3+ to memory_profiler changed time.clock() to time.time();  changed memory_usage_resources() to memory_usage()  I tweaked the code a little bit to make it work as follows  ---------------------------------------------------------------- import memory_profiler import random import time  names = ['John', 'Corey', 'Adam', 'Steve', 'Rick', 'Thomas'] majors = ['Math', 'Engineering', 'CompSci', 'Arts', 'Business']  print('Memory (Before): {} Mb'.format(memory_profiler.memory_usage()))  def people_list(num_people):     result = []     for i in range(num_people):         person = {             'id': i,             'name': random.choice(names),             'major': random.choice(majors)                      }         result.append(person)     return result  def people_generator(num_people):     for i in range(num_people):         person = {             'id': i,             'name': random.choice(names),             'major': random.choice(majors)                      }         yield person   t1 = time.time() #people = people_list(1000000) people = people_generator(1000000) # converting to list loses the benefits of having the generator   #people = list(people_generator(1000000)) t2 = time.time()  print('Memory (After): {} Mb'.format(memory_profiler.memory_usage())) print('Took {} Seconds'.format(t2-t1))import memory_profiler import random import time   names = ['John', 'Corey', 'Adam', 'Steve', 'Rick', 'Thomas'] majors = ['Math', 'Engineering', 'CompSci', 'Arts', 'Business']   print('Memory (Before): {} Mb'.format(memory_profiler.memory_usage()))   def people_list(num_people):     result = []     for i in range(num_people):         person = {             'id': i,             'name': random.choice(names),             'major': random.choice(majors)                      }         result.append(person)     return result   def people_generator(num_people):     for i in range(num_people):         person = {             'id': i,             'name': random.choice(names),             'major': random.choice(majors)                      }         yield person   t1 = time.time() #people = people_list(1000000) people = people_generator(1000000) # converting to list loses the benefits of having the generator   #people = list(people_generator(1000000)) t2 = time.time()   print('Memory (After): {} Mb'.format(memory_profiler.memory_usage())) print('Took {} Seconds'.format(t2-t1))

author: @HarmanHundal01
text: My notes from this video.   def square(x):     return x*x   # Here we have assigned the value returned by a function to a variable f = square(5)  print(square)  # This prints <function square at 0x000001C53F002950> print(f)  # This prints 25 i.e. the value stored in thir variable using the function   # However , we can also set a variable to a function( and not the value returned by the function) f = square  # On printing both f and square, we see that they are both stored at the same location and produce the same result when invoked print(square)  # Prints <function square at 0x0000023512DAF730> print(f)  # Prints <function square at 0x0000023512DAF730> print(square(5))  # Prints 25 print(f(5))  # Prints 25    # We can also pass functions as arguments and return functions as a result of other functions  # If a function accepts other functions as an argument or returns functions as an output, they are called higher order functions    # Example: Passing a function as an argument to a function # A great example of this is the map function which takes a function and an array as its argument   def my_map(func, arg_list):     result = []     for i in arg_list:         result.append(func(i))     return result     # Note: we don't add parenthesis when we pass a function to another function. A parenthesis means that it is going to be executed. But we aren't executing it. We're merely passing it.  squares = my_map(square, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) print(squares)    def cube(x):     return x**3     cubes = my_map(cube, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]) print(cubes)    # Example: Return a function from a function   def logger(msg):     # log_message is a function within the logger function     def log_message():         print('log', msg)     # We are returning the log_message function as aresult of this code     return log_message   log_hi = logger('Hi') log_hi()   # Another, more practical example   def html_tag(tag):     def wrap_text(msg):         print('<{0}>{1}</{0}>'.format(tag, msg))     return wrap_text     # print_h1 has become equal to the 'wraptext' function with the h1 tag remembered by it. print_h1 = html_tag('h1') print_h1('Test Headline!') print_h1('Another Headline!')    # print_p has become equal to the 'wraptext' function with the p tag remembered by it. print_p = html_tag('p') print_p('Test Paragraph!')    # People use this functionality for logging # In Python this is similar to using decorators

text: important thing to notice ,this is nested function that why when looking for variable in local function its sees if that variable in the enclosing function and then in the global then in the built in (LEGB RULE) notice is that not the other way aroun meaning if i do this:  def add(x,y):     return x+y+msg  def apply(fun,msg):     return fun  x=apply(add,1) x(1,2) ==>error message not found    beacause it look into the local then the global then built-in scopes ,and not looking in the apply scope so its not actually remembering its looking within the LEGB scpoe from write to left noe vice versa ,so   def logger(msg):     def log_message():         print('log',msg)     return log_message  x=logger('hi') x() x here have the definition of log_message function  and when we execute  x()  the return statement ned variable called msg so it look at the local scope not found ,then goes to enclosing scope which is logger function and it found it msg='hi',because when we call loger function eailer x=logger('hi') we assign msg='hi'  so that will happen when it doesnot find tag1:  tag1='a' def logger(tag):     def wrap_text(msg):             print('<{0}>{1}</{0}>'.format(tag1,msg))     return wrap_text  x=logger('h1') x('hello')

author: @user-xc5xf8gp8n
text: summary:  First class function is a function that behvaes like a first class citizen(or entity). That is, functions that behave like normal variables. That means that it can be an input and output for another function, and stored as an variable.    Those functions that inputs and outputs another function is called a higher class function. If a function is passed in without a bracket, python just refers to the code, and does not execute(run) it. IN that form we can treat the function just like any other variables, and that is how it is possible to make it an input or output for another function.

author: @AhmadShrif
text: Big fan of your tutorials, very well done and very organized. I would like you to point to an error in your javascript code at 6:27. The error you got can be resolved by adding arg_list[i]) not i to the func() as below:  function my_map(func, arg_list){   result = [];   for(var i = 0; i < arg_list.length; i++){       result.push(func(arg_list[i]));   }   return result; }  The fix you did will only work if the arg_list is starting with 1 and incrementing by 1. Because you will always operate on the index numbers not the item in that index.

text: i like to think of a function returning a function in terms of a factory, like so:  def car_factory(manufacturer):    def car(onomatopoeia):     print(manufacturer + " says " + onomatopoeia)    return car  porsche = car_factory("Porsche") porsche("vroom!") >>  Porsche says vroom! porsche("zioom!") >> Porsche says zioom!  jeep = car_factory("Jeep") jeep("bam! bam!") >> Jeep says bam! bam! jeep("raagh!") >> Jeep says raagh!  i.e. factory sets the type of the car they are going to sell, and the car makes the sound.

author: @meatyout
text:
Thanks, Corey! Great tutorial as always. However, I think it's important to make it clear that the examples you're giving are just intended to illustrate the concepts of first-class/higher-order functions, etc., and that the same results can be achieved in a more simple and/or readable way: Examples 1 & 2: def exp_list(exp, lst): exped = [i ** exp for i in lst] return exped print(exp_list(2, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5])) # outputs [1, 4, 9, 16, 25] print(exp_list(3, [1, 2, 3, 4, 5])) # outputs [1, 8, 27, 64, 125] Example 4: def wrap_text(tag, txt): print(f"<{tag}>{txt}") wrap_text("h1", "This is a headline") # outputs

This is a headline

wrap_text("p", "This is a paragraph") # outputs

This is a paragraph

author: @misiekt.1859
text: I would mention that in last example You are just creating an object with hidden method call. Also sometimes you say that function "remembers" value, as if this is some special case, while its just object storing data. IMO this would be easier to understand and reason with, while retaining functionality:   class html_tag:     def __init__(s,tag):         s.tag=tag     def wrap_text(s,msg):         print('<{s.tag}>{msg}</{s.tag}>'.format(**locals()))    h1=html_tag('h1') h1.wrap_text('text') h1.wrap_text('another text')

text: Another use case is to allow a user to select what type of algorithm they want to use for a solver. Also useful for profiling different functions which perform the same task.

author: @artihlec
text: 6:30 Corey, you a little bit messed up with your JS my_map function :). It behaves in this particular case as its python counterpart only because an array has values [1,2,3,4,5], try to change items in an array(list) and JS results will do not match with python results. It should look like this:  function square(x) {     return x * x; }  function my_map(func, arg_list) {     const result = [];     for (var i = 0; i < arg_list.length; i++) {         result.push(func(arg_list[i]))     }     return result; }  var squares = my_map(square, [1,2,3,4,5])  console.log(squares) BTW. I've been watching you for a wile and today actually decided to subscribe. A good and useful channel, a good explanation.

author: @iautomatecloud9305
text: Hi Corey, thanks for your videos. It certainly helps me clarify concepts and I appreciate what you are contributing to the community. It all works as an explanation, however there are two errors in your JS code that impact the result. Below is version 1.1. I've added it here so other viewers can see a working example of cube and square would get the expected result. I don't think markdown works here, so hopefully other viewers will be able to understand the code in this format. ``` function cube(x){     return x * x * x; } function square(x){     return x * x;     } function my_map(func, arg_list){     result = [];     //for(var i = 1; i <= arg_list.length; i++){ // using <= results in an over shoot of the array elements when using i=0, first element   //of the array.     for(var i = 0; i < arg_list.length; i++){         //result.push(func(i));  // this has to change else only the value of I is passed.          result.push(func(arg_list[i]));     }     return result; } var cubes1 = my_map(cube, [1,2,3,4,5,6,7])  var cubes11 = my_map(cube, [2,3,3,4,5,6,7]) // this will not work in the previous version.  console.log(cubes1); // this works only because the order is passed console.log(cubes11); // this will not cube correctly in the previous version. ```

author: @clintkadera8331
text: Hey Corey, I enjoyed learning about first-class functions. I believe the my_map function in-video has a logic error. If arg_list isn't consecutive (e.g. [1, 5, 3, 4, 5]), the function output is wrong. I fixed the logic error using the algorithm below:  function myMap(func, argList){ result = []; for(var i = 0; i < argList.length; i++){ result.push(func(argList[i])); } return result; }  If I overlooked something, please let me know. Thanks! Clint

author: @arkates3625
text: Correct me if im wrong, but is the reason for using functions in other functions to easily create new functions? Example: def wrapwithsymbol(symbol):     def wraptext(text) :         print("{0}\n{1}\n{0}".format(symbol * len(text), text))          return wraptext   So what we can do now is easily create functions like: wrap_equal = wrapwithsynbol("=") wrap_equal("great video btw") >>> =============== great video btw =============== So what I want to know is if this is the right way of using them and if it is, is it the only scenario when you want to use them?

author: @LlewellynvonHellen
text: First class functions can be assigned as variables/arguments; variables/arguments can be assigned as first class functions. If a function is the result of a function or takes an argument of a function, then that function is called a _higher order_ function.
